etymologies: Old English flotian (verb), of Germanic origin and related to fleet, reinforced in Middle English by Old French floter, also from Germanic

definitions: rest or move on or near the surface of a liquid without sinking

examples.text: she relaxed, floating gently in the water

shortDefinitions: rest or move on surface or liquid

definitions: cause (a buoyant object) to rest or move on the surface of a liquid without sinking

examples.text: trees were felled and floated downstream

shortDefinitions: cause to float

definitions: be suspended freely in a liquid or gas

examples.text: fragments of chipped cartilage floated in the joint

shortDefinitions: be suspended in liquid or gas

definitions: move or hover slowly and lightly in a liquid or the air; drift

examples.text: clouds floated across a brilliant blue sky
through the open window floated the sound of traffic

shortDefinitions: move or hover in liquid or air

definitions: (of a rumor, idea, etc.) circulate

examples.text: the notion was floating around Capitol Hill

shortDefinitions: move or hover in liquid or air

definitions: (in sports) make (the ball) travel lightly and effortlessly through the air

examples.text: he floated the kick into the net

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: cause ball to travel lightly and effortlessly

definitions: (of a sight or idea) come before the eyes or mind

examples.text: the advice his father had given him floated into his mind

shortDefinitions: come before eyes or mind

definitions: put forward (an idea) as a suggestion or test of reactions.
shortDefinitions: put forward idea

definitions: offer the shares of (a company) for sale on the stock market for the first time.
shortDefinitions: sell shares of company on stock market for first time

definitions: (of a currency) fluctuate freely in value in accordance with supply and demand in the financial markets

examples.text: a policy of letting the pound float

shortDefinitions: (of currency) fluctuate freely in value according to supply and demand

definitions: allow (a currency) to fluctuate in value.
shortDefinitions: allow currency to do this

definitions: a thing that is buoyant in water.
shortDefinitions: thing that floats

definitions: a small object attached to a fishing line to indicate by moving when a fish bites.
shortDefinitions: object attached to fishing line to show when fish bites

definitions: a cork or buoy supporting the edge of a fishing net.
shortDefinitions: cork etc. supporting edge of fishing net

definitions: a hollow or inflated organ enabling an organism (such as the Portuguese man-of-war) to float in the water.
shortDefinitions: organ enabling organism to float

definitions: a hollow structure fixed underneath an aircraft enabling it to take off and land on water.
shortDefinitions: structure enabling aircraft to take off and land on water

definitions: a device floating on the surface of a liquid that forms part of a valve apparatus controlling flow in and out of the enclosing container, e.g., in a toilet tank or a carburetor.
shortDefinitions: part of valve apparatus controlling flow of water

definitions: a platform mounted on a truck and carrying a display in a parade
shortDefinitions: platform on truck carrying display in procession

definitions: a hand tool with a rectangular blade used for smoothing plaster or concrete.
shortDefinitions: tool for smoothing plaster

definitions: a soft drink with a scoop of ice cream floating in it
shortDefinitions: soft drink with scoop of floating ice cream

definitions: (in critical path analysis) the period of time by which the duration of an activity may be extended without affecting the overall time for the process.
shortDefinitions: in critical path analysis
